titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 4. VI. Thursday.
Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures Present Adams, Tillinghast, Vail

The Petitions of Adam Brookes and of Morsell and others were read—conversation, no question— H.R.U.S. Howard reports Call on P.U.S. for documents respecting capture and restoration of Ship Genl. Urrea; postponed for me to prepare an amendment— Comee. of the whole on the Union Potter of Pennsylvania’s speech— Murray of Kentuckey moves Comee to rise— Adjourned 3. P.M.
5. V:30 Friday

Sitting to Clevenger H.R.U.S. I moved to suspend the rules to take up Howard’s call on P:U.S. with my amendment. House refused 79 to 117. Message from P.U.S. to repress popular movements on Niagara frontier—referred to Comee. on foreign Relations— Fillmore’s motion to suspend the rules—fails— Reports of Comees— Howard’s call comes up— My Amendment— Fillmore’s Amendment on that— Howard opposes both— And Hamer—Cilley, F. O. J. Smith—Bronson— Patton gives up— Rhett’s double motion to adjourn over to Monday and to adjourn fails—both amendments and call pass—adjourn over to Monday— Corwin
6. II:45. Saturday— Tillinghast, W. S. Smith—Mrs Smith— Letter to Origen Bacheler— At Clevenger’s—sitting for Bust— Met G. Kemble—and J. Reed— Letter to S. J. May

7. VI. Sunday. Heard Fowler 1. Chronicles 29.29.30. remarkable discourse— Mrs Frye— Catherine Johnson to dine, P.M at St John’s Church. Mr Hawley— 1. Sunday after Epiphany— Stranger preached from Hebrews 2.3— Walk with Catherine home to Mr Frye’s Letter from R Buchanan— Walking home, call at Mr W. S. Smith’s— Letter to George Collings— Visits from General Gratiot and Mr Nicolet—

8. V:30. Monday— Pedrich— Lyon for subscription to Wilbur Fisk’s travels— Sitting to Clevenger— H.R.U.S. four Messages from P.U.S— Answers to the 3. Calls—referred to the Comee. of Ways and Means and foreign Affairs—debate. Fillmore Bronson—Rhett—W. Thompson—Menefee—Wise— Petitions—Seeley—Jeremiah Day and 25. of New Haven— Stop’d Petitions atCilley’s talk about N.E. boundary— Cushing’s proposed communication to Legislature of Massachusetts.

9. IV:30. Tuesday— Sitting half an hour to Clevenger— H.R.U.S— Reports of Committees— Resolutions— Letter to N. Herbemont— Comee. of the Whole on the Union upon the Message— Cushing’s proposed Resolution— Administration sub-treasury Speech of Murray of Kentucky— Garland moves Comee. to rise— 65 members in the House— Resolutions— Adjourn at 3— Senate Chamber— Calhoun and Clay—Preston—Crittenden— Bouldin introduced Baptis & others, members of Virginia Senate— Raw Note from R Jones with Inventory of T. B. A.
10. V:30. Wednesday—

Sitting of 1/4 of an hour to Clevenger. H.R.U.S— M’Kay chairman of Military Committee moves to discharge the Comee. of the whole on the Union from the consideration of the Report of the Secretary of War, and to refer it to that Committee—debate— Bell of Tennessee Motion extending the Resolution to discharge the Committee of the whole on the Union from the further consideration of all Hayne’s resolutions but that now in discussion before it which was finally adopted— House adjourned about 3— In the Senate chamber— Calhoun’s 5th. Resolution— Clay’s amendment— Crittenden, Buchanan, Webster, Clay— Calhoun, who finally votes for Clay’s Substitute, to his Resolution— Met Gales—another disaster in Florida— Bird here— I spoke to Underwood in his behalf; and to Heman Allen, for the widow of Genl. Brown— Mr Frye here this Evening—and Mr & Mrs W. S. Smith— Jackson’s Letter.
11. VI. Thursday—

Dr. Mayo here— Copy of Jackson’s Letter and endorsement upon the cover of Mayo’s Letter to him— Tardy at the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, Tillinghast and Foster there— Naylor had been there— No Quorum— Petition for repeal of duty on Starch— Biddle, Hunter, Slade, Vail, Webster absent. H.RU.S— Letter from Dorsey, the Sergeant at arms to the Speaker— Debate— Select Comee. of 5. Reports of Comees. Resolns. My call for Gorostiza’s pamphlet, and the name of the foreign Minister— Howard moves to strike out the name—debate— Howard Menefee, Waddy Thompson, Haynes— Adjourn 1/2 past 3. Dr. Huntt had been here— I delivered Letter to W. C. Dawson— Chairman of Comee. of Mileage.
12. V. Friday—

Dr. Mayo here again this morning, with Letter to W. S. Fulton— Revd. Mr Johnson with Subscription for repairing Pohick Church— Metropolis and Washington Banks— Clevenger’s— H.R.US. Report of Comee. of Elections—on the Mississippi Election— Postponed till Tuesday— Private Bills— Three Comees. of the Whole— M’Kay, Casey W. B. Calhoon Chairman, successfully.— Downes—Nourse—Fillebrown— Attempt to adjourn over to Monday failed— Adjourned at 4— T. B. J. Frye and Catherine Johnson dined with us—
13. V:30. Saturday

At Niles’s Register Office— Clevenger’s before and after the House’s Session— HRU.S. Reports of Comees.— My Call for the name of the foreign Minister— Shields—Holsey, Cushing— Hour expired— Private Bills—many passed— Appropriation for Minister to Mexico 28. Feby 1837. Inquiry for the Bills— Library— Vattel— T. B. J. Frye and Catherine Johnson dined here— Midshipman J. Q. A jr came in from Norfolk— R.Menefee here. Semi-official Pamphlet. War in Texas. A. Jackson’s Letter to W. S. Fulton.
14. VII. Sunday
Heard at Presbyterian Church Mr Hopkins, brother in Law to Mr Fowler from Acts 18.17 [“]And Gallio cared for none of these things”— Psalm 138. v 4. Watts—

lg.l: Amidst a thousand snares I stand,
Upheld and guarded by thy hand;
Thy words my fainting soul revive,
And keep my dying faith alive.

div.p: No Church this afternoon at St. John’s— I heard Mr Fowler from Exodus 32–26— Then Moses stood in the gate of the camp, and said, who is on the Lord’s side? My wife was confined all day to her bed with a very severe attack of Erisypelas— Letters to Anthony Collamore—S. C. Phillips and Major J. H. Hook. The day consumed in filing Petitions and assorting Papers— Elizabeth came down to dinner—
15. V. Monday

My wife is confined to her bed with a very severe attack of Erisypelas, and had a restless night. Mrs Goods watched. She was this day better— Dr Huntt was here; himself dying with a consumption— H.R.U.S— Petitions beginning with Virginia; going South and West; and then back from Wisconsin through to Maine— There were a great multitude of Abolition and Anti-Texas petitions from all the free States—all laid on the table— I presented nearly sixty myself. Also the Petition of Benoit Henri Klimkiewitz a Polish exile, for a grant of land— Mr Ungerer had brought it to me at the door of the Hall. It was referred to the Committee on the public Lands— The Petition of 54 citizens of Ohio that Congress would carry into execution the 10th. article of the Treaty of Ghent. Haynes instantly moved to lay it on the table, but I asked that the Article should be read by the Clerk and it was read Petition laid on the table— A Petition that Congress would repeal the Law in the District of Columbia, by which Freemen are liable to be sold for Jail fees— I moved its reference to the Committee on the District of Columbia with Instructions to report a Bill to
abolish imprisonment for debt in the District— The Speaker entertained this motion. Haynes, moved to make it an enquiry into the expediency but for once the House deserted him and the petition was referred with the Instruction— The House adjourned at 4. Mr Samuel Whitcomb was here after dinner, and Mrs Smith in the Evening— Whitcomb spoke much of Jotham Lincoln, and George Bancroft, now collector of the customs at Boston; and of his own desire to be appointed Door keeper of the House of Representatives—and my time is so absorbed that my Diary is again running into irretrievable arrears
16. V:15 Tuesday.

Mr Ratcliff here again this morning, with a memorial to Congress for the Canal across the Isthmus of Panama— Left a copy with me— Call at Office of the Commissioner of Pensions— Left with him the papers on the pension claim of Wait Wadsworth, received from G. B. Weston—and spoke of Mrs Lawrance’s claim, presented this morning by Samuel Whitcomb, as requested by the Letter which I gave him yesterday from James C Doane— H.RUS. Mississippi election— Bronson offers a Resolution that Prentiss and Word, are not members of the House— Long debate whether they shall have seats at or within the bar— Claiborne’s written statement—question upon its being printed— Statement by Prentiss, printed, laid on the tables of members yesterday. Words between Gholson and Wise— Dawson’s privileged motion—discussed and laid on the table— C. F. Mercer’s motion to require the two members not to pursue their quarrel, any further— Motion to lay it on the table rejected by yeas and naysfurther debate— House adjourned at 1/2 past S. L Southard came to me, to enquire as to our title East of the Mississippi River, by the Louisiana Treaty— Returned the miniature enamel’d to A. H. Sheppard— Delivered a letter to S. S. Southworth— J. Q. A. 2d. dined at W S. Smith’s, assorting petitions.
17. V:15. Wednesday.
Sitting of an hour this morning to Mr Clevenger, and again half an hour after the adjournment of the House

H.R.U.S— It was resolved yesterday to take up the Mississippi election every day at one O’Clock until it shall be decided— After the reading of the Journal Patton moved to lay on the table the Resolution offered yesterday by C. F. Mercer, requiring of Gholson and Wise that they should pursue their quarrel no further— And it was laid on the table by yeas and nays— I found among the papers on the tables of members a report made by Birdsall of New-York from the Committee of Revolutionary claims against the Petition of John and Nathaniel Thomas— I immediately saw Parmenter, and A. H. Sheppard members of the Committee and afterwards Birdsall, and with their consent had the report recommitted to furnish the Evidence which was wanting— At one O’ Clock, the Mississippi election was taken up— Bell of Tennessee moved two Resolutions as amendment to Bronson’s Resolution declaring that Prentiss and Word are not members of the House of Representatives— Bell’s first Resolution is to rescind that passed at the special Session declaring Gholson and Claiborne elected members of the 25th. Congress— The second declares Prentiss and Word duly elected and entitled to their Seats— The Speaker informed Messrs. Prentiss and Word that the House were ready to hear them in support of their claim to seats; and Prentiss addressed the House in a Speech of two hours, full of Spirit, and of argument; seldom surpassed as a specimen of eloquence in that house. He reviewed the former decision of the House, and proved that it was not irreversible as res judicata— He commented with keen severity upon the report of the Committee of elections, upon the suppression by Gholson and Claiborne of their Credentials at the special Session, upon their
positive averments that the People of Mississippi had positive universally believed that the election of July was for the whole Congress;—and upon the disregard to principle in the decision of the house— At 3. the House adjourned, leaving his Speech unfinished— Midshipman John Quincy Adams, with his companion Reynolds came to the House, and I introduced them to the Ladies Gallery— John Quincy dined abroad— Mr Frye and Mrs Smith were here this evening— Mr Frye had a Letter of 27. December from Robert Buchanan, who had been in the battle of the 25th. with Sam— Jones— I found the copies of the two Letters from General Washington to Genl. Thomas— My wife who I had flattered myself was nearly recovered had this evening a severe return of fever—
18. IV:30. Thursday.

Mr Cook is a partner of a company of Pinmakers in the City of New-York who have a memorial before Congress referred to the Committee of Manufactures, praying for the repeal of the duty upon brass wire; and he brought me Letters of introduction from Charles King and James Herring— At my request he attended the meeting of the Committee, at which were present, Adams, Biddle Naylor, Tillinghast, Vail— Absent Foster, Hunter, Slade Webster— Mr Cook addressed the Committee on the grounds of the Memorial.— It appears there is a company of Brass-wire manufacturers at Waterbury Connt. and the Comee. wished to take some information how they might be affected by the repeal of the duty— The Memorials, relating to Starch, and to Tallow and Oil, and Baron Roenne’s Letter concerning linen-tapes were read; by which the hour was consumed— The silk memorials were postponed, at Mr Biddle’s suggestion, on account of the absence of Mr Slade— H.R.U.S— Reports of Committees, received, occupied nearly the whole of the first hour—12 minutes only were left for my call for Gorostiza’s pamphlet, and the name— Mr Cushing who had the floor
informed the House, that he had received from the British Minister Mr Fox assurances that he had never communicated a copy of the pamphlet to Mr Forsyth, nor ever made any remark to him concerning it— Mr Cushing said also that Gorostiza’s pamphlet had never been published— He postponed his further remarks— From 1 till 3. Mr Prentiss resumed his argument in support of his election and that of Mr Word— It was not inferior to that of yesterday— I attended less to it, for I thought the demonstration yesterday so complete that any thing further was superfluous— I gave Mr Parmenter, a member of the Committee of Revolutionary Claims the first Volume of the Journals of the Revolutionary Congress, containing the several appointments of General John Thomas in 1775 and 1776.— The copies of the two Letters from General Washington to him in April and May 1776—and the letter from Thomas P. Beal to me authenticating the genealogy of the two Sons, the petitioners—John and Nathaniel Thomas. Mr Reed requested and I gave him the Memorial of William Jackson and others for the repeal of the duties on Tallow and Olive oil of which he wanted a copy—for the opposing interest of the Nantucket Whalemen— Adjourned at 3.— I called at Mr Clevenger’s room but he was not there— Met R. Peters who had been at death’s door, but has so far recovered that he looks quite well— Overtook and walked with Legare to his lodgings at Mrs Ulrichs— Evening absorbed in filing and assorting papers— My dear wife is still confined to her bed— Dr Huntt was here—a skeleton with hardly a breath of life remaining in him— As I was returning home from the Capitol Mr Cook accosted me, and enquired what the Committee had done— I told him— Mr Fillmore shewed me a Resolution which he proposed to offer concerning M’Nab’s violation of our territory—
Seaton and Markoe.
19. V. Friday—

As I was coming through the Rotundo homeward yesterday, Mr Seaton, and Mr Markoe stopped me and informed me that I had been unanimously elected President of the American Historical Society—and that they had also passed a vote requesting me at any time during the approaching Spring to deliver an Address before the Society— They said there was a Committee appointed to inform me of my election— I said I had no other objection to accepting that Office than the sense of my own unworthiness to fill it: but that it would be impossible for me to deliver the Address for want of time to prepare it.— This morning Mr Ratcliff called and I returned to him the copy of his Petition for public encouragement to the undertaking to open a ship Canal over the Isthmus of Panama— He said he had only one copy of the Petition, which he hoped to have presented by Mr Southard to the Senate— I advised him to have a copy of it presented to the House by Mr Curtis, the member from the city of New-York, who he said was favourable to the plan, and I promised him any assistance that it would be in my power to give.— HR.U.S— Fillmore offered his resolution of call concerning M’Nab’s Expedition to Schlosser— Objection was made— He moved the suspension of the rules, and I asked for the yeas and nays, but both were refused— Prentiss finished his argument in support of his right to represent the People of the State of Mississippi— Mr Word said that his colleague had so fully set forth the claim which he had in common with him, that he did not deem it necessary to occupy the time of the House with any observations of his own— Gholson made a short, feeble, but not indecorous Speech without the attempt to answer the argument of Prentiss—but holding to his intrenchment behind the decision of the House at the special Session— Foster of New-York began a full dress speech; but soon after 3 the House adjourned leaving him to finish to-morrow.— I gave to Mr Webster 17. abolition, and
anti-Texas Petitions addressed to the Senate— After the adjournment I went into the Library and found in Gordon’s History of the Revolutionary War passages respecting General John Thomas which I marked to shew to-morrow to the members of the Comee. of Revolutionary claims— My wife was again this day better, but still keeps her bed. Mr Prentiss was introduced to me after the adjournment, and told me that he came from the yankee breed— He is a native of Maine.
20. V. Satruday

I answered a Letter from Samuel Webb, and William H. Scott of Philadelphia, inviting me to deliver an Address to the Pennsylvania Hall Association, upon the opening of the Hall which they are erecting in that City for free discussion, to be opened about the first week in May— I declined. H.R.U.S. The Committee of Foreign Relations reported a Bill, appropriating five Millions of dollars, of indemnity to the claimants on account of French Spoliations prior to 1800— They offered also a Resolution requesting the President to negotiate with the Government of Demark for indemnity on account of the prizes sent into the port of Bergen by the squadron of Paul Jones in 1779. and delivered up at the demand of the English Consul— Mr Taliaferro, moved as an amendment that the request to the President should be to carry into execution the Resolution of the old Continental Congress on the subject— This gave rise to a debate, which at one O’Clock was arrested by the order of the day the Mississippi election— Mr Foster continued his speech for two hours without approaching to a conclusion, in support of the decision of the House at the special Session— Foster is a fluent Speaker, and is one of the very few Northern Administration men, who dares occasionally to have an opinion of his own— He voted against the gag; and the labour that he has taken to justify this absurd violation of the right of Election by which the House have manufactured two
members of Congress for the People of the State of Mississippi, I believe was dictated far more by the qualms of his own conscience than from an expectation that it was needed or would have any influence on the present decision of the House— The decision in October was a dogged party vote; and so it will be now— Foster agonizes to justify his vote to his own mind— I met Mr Birdsall this morning in the Library, and pointed out to him the passage in Gordon’s History of the Revolutionary War, relating to the death of General John Thomas in Canada, in June 1776— I found similar passages in Mrs Warren’s and Dr. Ramsay’s histories— I consulted also Andrews and Botta, but found no notice of him in them— I gave Mr Taliaferro minutes however of the three vouchers which I found— This evening Joseph John Gurney, an English Quaker, visited me with Bartholomew Wistar, one of the same Society, belonging to Philadelphia who had formerly visited me at Quincy with ElizabethGurney has obtained permission to preach to morrow morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives and invited me to attend; which I promised— Thomas B. J. Frye dined with us. [symbols]
21. VI:30 Sunday.

I took my two Granddaughters with me this morning to the Hall of the House of Representatives, and heard Joseph John Gurney deliver a discourse of about two hours, upon Christianity according to his conception of it, which he said was precisely the contents of the New Testament, without addition, without diminution, and without compromise.— His manner of speaking is fluent—but slow and deliberate; very moderately animated, and with very little action of gesture.— He had not the canting tone, usual with quaker preachers, but had occasionally the prefix of inarticulate sound, which they employ when the word they want is not ready to slip from the tongue— His doctrine was strictly trinitarion and calvinistic; and his
quotations from scripture copious and always ready— The house was crowded so that we were indebted to kindness and civility for Seats— Mr Van Buren was one of the auditory— After the discourse and a short prayer and benediction, I went up and shook hands with him, and with his companion—Friends— Miss Johnston and Thomas Frye dined with us.— After dinner I attended alone at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 3d. Sunday after Epiphany, and a short discourse from 2. Corinthians Ecclesiastes 9.3. “This is an evil among all things that are done under the sun, that there is one event unto all: yea also, the heart of the sons of men is full of evil, and madness is in their heart while they live, and after that they go to the dead.”— I received this Evening a Letter, anonymous, from Greensborough in the State of Alabama—
22— VI:30 Monday.

My dear wife is we hope recovering, and was up all this day; but does not yet leave her chamber— H.R.U.S— It was Petition day—but Horace Everett had last Monday presented the Memorial of John Ross and a delegation of Cherokee Indians, remonstrating against Schermerhorn’s fraudulent Treaty— He now moved that it should be referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs (of which he is a member) with instructions to report the facts— Haynes of Georgia moved to lay the whole subject on the table—a vote was taken by rising—no Quorum— The yeas and nays were called—no Quorum called a second time and ordered 86 against to 83 for laying on the table— Haynes moved the indefinite postponement of the whole subject— The Speaker said the motion to commit takes precedence of the motion for indefinite postponement.— Owens moved again to lay the whole subject on the table— Everett called for the yeas and nays and they were 93 to 94— Arphaxed Loomis voted against laying on the table— Haynes seeing how the vote had turned said; well if we must have a Cherokee
War, let it come, as well now, as at any time— Loomis was frightened out of his wits at the result of his own vote, and said he had voted under the impression that there was to be no debate— If there was to be, he should regret his vote— Everett apologized and disclaimed, and protested that he was exceedingly unwilling to debate the question, if the house would but refer it to the Committee, but the Georgians shewed no symptom of yielding— Everett proceeded about five minutes when the Speaker said it was one O’Clock, and announced the order of the day—the Mississippi Election. Noyes of Maine moved to suspend the rules, to call the States for Petitions, but the motion was rejected— Foster resumed his speech, and prosed two hours and a half, about every thing but the question, about it, Goddess and about it; without coming to a conclusion, and at half past 3. the house adjourned. Foster is a young lawyer—never at a loss for words; and not wanting in intelligence— An argufier with a little conscience, and just logic and rhetoric enough to drown her in floods of sophistical reasoning.— Joseph L. Williams came to my seat and told me that he had voted for the Resolution of the 21st of December, with great reluctance and against his better judgment— He enquired as to my intention to move to rescind that resolution— I said I should wait till petitions should come in for the rescinding, as I expected them in great numbers— But they will be of no use— We had much conversation upon this subject. Mrs Smith was here this Evening—
23. V. Tuesday.

H.R.U.S. There was an entry on the Journal that Hopkins of Virginia had moved the reconsideration of the vote yesterday against laying the Cherokee Memorial on the table, and a decision of the Speaker from which Mercer had appealed— Hopkins this morning said he did not yesterday move the reconsideration, and the Journal was accordingly corrected, and Mercer’s appeal was withdrawn— But Hopkins now moved the reconsideration—to be taken up hereafter— Cambreleng moved a suspension of the rules to go into Committee
of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up two Bills—one of partial appropriation of one Million of dollars, for the suppression of Indian hostilities— The other of 625000 dollars for the defence of the Northern frontier— The House accordingly went into Committee Connor of North-Carolina in the Chair, and the day was consumed in acrimonious and inflammatory debate on the Indian Appropriation Bill— There was a Letter from the Secretary of War, urging for an instant appropriation for the Florida Campaign, which Wise opposed on the ground that he would consent to no further appropriation till the House should institute an enquiry into the causes and conduct of the War in Florida— Downing the Delegate from the Territory then came out with a violent attack upon Wise, upon all the opposition to the administration, whom he charged with being the cause of the expense and protraction of the War—upon the Cherokee Delegation, sent by the Secretary of War to mediate with the Seminole Indians, and upon the abolitionists who petition for the abolition of Slavery in the Territories— This engaged an altercation between Downing and Wise which was followed by speeches from Cilley of Maine, Waddy Thompson, Haynes of Georgia, Bell of Tennessee, and Everett, and Robertson, all embroiling the whole subject more and more— Wise found himself charged with being an abolitionist, and cowered under the charge more than I have ever seen him before— Thompson imputed his siding with the Indians to morbid sensibility— Bell deserted him, and said he should have reserved his opposition for the time when the remainder of the appropriation should be moved for.— He finally moved to reduce the appropriation from one Million to 500000 dollars— There were calls to rise and report the Bill, but at 1/2 past four Biddle took the floor—a motion was made for the Committee to rise, and carried 81 to 73—and the House adjourned. Mary and Elizabeth and Midshipman John Quincy went and passed the Evening at Mr W. S. Smith’s.— T. T. Whittlesey one of the
members from Connecticut who voted against the Resolution of 21. Decr. sought a conversation with me upon the subject, and asked my opinion of the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia &c— I told him I had always been against it; and that I thought the South had been ill advised in putting the issue upon the right of petition— I said I should move to rescind that Resolution— He said he must adhere to the vote he had given for this Session because it would otherwise appear as if he had yielded to a threat; but at the next Session he would vote for referring the Petitions—
24. V:45. Wednesday

Called with Midshipman John Quincy Adams, and his Sister Elizabeth at the House of Mr King the painter to see a portrait of him that he has been painting, and which is a good likeness— He applied this morning to the Secretary of the Navy for an extension of his furlough till the end of the month; but could not obtain it. He left us therefore this afternoon to go in the Railway cars to Baltimore; whence he is to proceed to Norfolk, there to join the sloop of war John Adams; bound on a cruise to the East-Indies— H.R.U.S— The House went immediately into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the two Appropriation Bills— Waddy Thompson made an explanation, taking back a part of his charges against the North, of hating the white people of the South— He now qualified the assertion by confining it to the abolitionists, and then to the violent abolitionists—but his real sentiment was what he said yesterday— Biddle had the floor and was beginning to notice the discussion of yesterday upon abolition, in a tone which instantly raised a call to order— The Chairman, Connor said that every allusion made yesterday to the subject of abolition was out of order; and that whenever it had been alluded to, he had intended to call the Speaker to order; but that just as he was about to remind them of the Rules of the House each of the Speakers had passed to another subject— Waddy Thompson said that as he, after the subject had been introduced by the member from Maine Cilley had been the person who made the remarks which Mr Biddle
appeared disposed to answer he hoped he would be allowed to proceed— Mr Biddle was accordingly proceeding when Patton called him to order, and insisted that the rules of the House should be observed— Biddle submitted; and passed to other parts of Downing’s Speech— He exposed with bold indignation, the private Letter from Jesup, to Blair, the Editor of the Globe, upon which President Jackson recalled General Scott from the command in Florida, and appointed Jesup to take his place— The base acquiescence of the Secretary of War Cass, to this injustice of Jackson— The censure by the court-martial which tried Scott upon this Letter.— The adulation of Jackson, by the Court in their notice of this transaction— The overbearing spirit of Jackson in sending back that part of their report to be expunged, and their tame submission to his order in expunging it. He concluded it with some forcible remarks upon the pernicious effects of favouritism and intrigue upon the moral character of the army; and upon young Officers— With the exception of rather overcharged panegyric upon Scott which gave the speech a partizan colouring it was admirable— He was followed by Underwood, Glascock, Bynum, and Pope, who brought the Committee back to the only question properly before them—the necessity of the appropriation; which was self-evident— Wise’s motion to reduce it without a count was rejected— Wise himself was absent—the other Bill, of appropriation for the Northern frontier was then taken up, and both Bills were reported to the House— Bynum had insisted in calling the yeas and nays on the Florida-Bill—they were 164 to 2. but there were about 40 members who did not vote— Adjourned about 4— On returning home, I found the Carriage at the door to take my nephew and namesake to the Cars— There was but time to bid him Godspeed— There was a Northern light in the Evening— I spent it chiefly in filing and assorting Letters—
25. IV:30. Thursday.

I attended before 11. O’Clock, at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures; but Mr Foster and Mr Slade, were the only other members who attended— There was no Quorum and nothing was done— It will be impossible to form a Quorum unless I give notice to every member, the day before every weekly return of the Meeting day— Naylor was yesterday called home to Philadelphia by the illness of his wife— Hunter of Virginia, taking no interest in manufactures, purposely abstains from attending, and there is no other member of the Committee who cares for any thing under their consideration— H.R.U.S. The Ante-diluvian claim upon Denmark, for Peter Landais & prizes sent to Bergen, and there delivered up, was postponed until to-morrow— Mr Cushing who dry nurses it being indisposed and absent— The hour till one was consumed in receiving Reports from Committees without getting through the list— Then came the Mississippi Election, and Foster in an hour and a half of the third day, finished his Speech— Fluent, verbose, pointless, tiresome, beyond measure— He was followed by Pennybacker another member of the Committee, not quite so fluent, but promising to be equally tedious and not less dull—behind whom when he rose was the alarming prospect of a third dissertation breeder in the person of Bronson— After Pennybacker had been droning along about half an hour; with about sixty members of the House in the Hall, not five of whom were listening to what he said, Rives of Virginia his colleague in mere compassion moved an adjournment— He suspended his motion at the request of Smith of Maine, to take up read and refer to Committee, five Bills from the Senate, one of which was for the increase of the army— Adjourned at 3. I had not walked far from the Capitol, when the Carriage with the children in it met me, and I rode home with them— Mrs Smith was here this afternoon— It was the day of the New Moon, and brought a change
from the beautiful weather which has prevailed almost without interruption these four months, to gloomy and lowering, but not cold. Sampson Mason of Ohio told me that he should on account of the illness of his wife, be obliged to go home immediately, and feared he should not be able to come back during the present Session of Congress— I began a Letter to my Son at the House, and finished it in the Evening at home—
26. V— Friday

H.R.U.S. Reports of Committees—few James Rariden a new member from Indiana asked leave to offer a Resolution, for providing the new Members with the books which have been furnished to the members of former Congresses— Objection made— Rariden moved a suspension of the Rules, which was carried—and then came the debate till the Speaker at one, called for the order of the day the Mississippi election— Mr Pennybacker then resumed his argument where he had left it yesterday, and continued about two hours more, in support of the Resolution of the House, and against the choice of the People of the State of Mississippi— He concluded just before 3. Maury of Tennessee, a member of the minority of the Committee of Elections then rose to speak, but there was a manifestation of a disposition to adjourn— Mr Bronson a majority member of the Committee declared his intention to speak briefly—and Legare on the same side, said he should ask perhaps half or three quarters of an hour and the house adjourned— I employed the time of the sitting in despatching documents— I wrote a short Letter to Anthony Collamore, and a long one in the Evening in answer to William Foster.
27. IV:45. Saturday

Rainy day— Call at the Pension-Office, and left with the Commissioner James L. Edwards the papers for a pension certificate to Susanna Delano, and
make enquiries concerning the claim of Jerusha Ripley— At the Metropolis and Washington Banks— H.R.U.S.— Mr Rariden’s Resolution to furnish the new Members of the House with the Books which have been furnished to the veterans, to be paid for from the contingent expenses of the House was the unfinished business of the morning hour— The usual debate between the economists and the liberals commenced yesterday was now continued till the expiration of the hour. Briggs moved an amendment which Rariden accepted that the books should be furnished to such members as should apply to the Clerk for them in writing— Sherrod Williams moved an amendment that the members of this and the two preceding Congresses who have received the books should return them to the Clerk for the use of their Successors— Rariden said there was nothing in this inconsistent with his Resolution, and that he was willing to vote for it as a separate Resolution, with the same modification that he had accepted to his own—that is that every member so disposed should return his books to the Clerk, and take his receipt as a voucher for his own justification and credit with his constituents— Hopkins at last smothered further debate by calling for the Previous Question which was carried— Bond of Ohio asked for the yeas and nays, on the previous question but they were refused— They were taken however on the main question, and the Resolution was carried . . .3 to 70—with about 30 dodgers— The order of the day, the Mississippi election ensued— Maury of Tennessee a member of the minority of the Committee, who had taken the floor, now said that he believed the majority of the House had their minds made up and were weary of the discussion— That most of his friends thought it would be most expedient to decide the question as soon as possible— He would therefore wave his right to the floor and not trouble the house with any remarks on the subject— Whereupon Bronson a majority member of the Committee rose to offer a few brief observations, and kept the House till 3. O’Clock treading over again the same track which his brazen brainless brothers Foster and Pennybacker had trodden of surplusage and suppressed credentials, and adjudication by the house &c.
At 3 O’Clock the fragment of a Quorum left in the house became so weary that they adjourned without hearing the close of Mr Bronson’s few remarks— It poured with rain— I went into the Library to hunt up some election cases in the British House of Commons—but Mr Bell had the books out— I looked at the 3 editions of Hennepin’s account of the discovery of the Mississippi of 1683 1696 and 1697.— Went into the Senate chamber and heard for half an hour a debate on a land pre-emption Bill— Left the Senate still in Session and walked through the rain about half way home; when I met the Carriage returning again for me after having been to the Capitol for me once, when Thomas was told I was gone— I rode home; my cloak wet through—and took cold of which I was sensible before going to bed—
28. V. Sunday.

Severe and almost disabling cold in the head— Heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler, from Matthew 11.28. “Come unto me, all ye that labour, and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest[”]— An affectionate exhortation to all his auditory to go to God.— Thomas Frye, and Catherine E. Johnston were here after the morning service— They are all going to morrow morning to Rockville, to a wedding. After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read prayers for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany, and preached from Zechariah 4.10. [“]For who hath despised the day of small things?” I answered a Letter from Mr John Marston of Taunton— It was my intention to have made some preparation for addressing the House; on the Mississippi election; but my voice is and will be so much affected by this cold, already aggravated by a sore throat that I am constrained to abandon the purpose; or if I am able to speak at all to say only a few words— I received this day 31. Petitions, and consumed the whole evening in
assorting, filing, endorsing and entering them on my list, without completing the work— With these Petitions I receive many Letters which I have not time to answer— Most of them are so flattering; and expressed in terms of such deep sensibility, that I am in imminent danger of being led by them into presumption, and puffed up with vanity— The abolition Newspapers—the Liberator, Emancipator, Philanthropist, National Enquirer and New-York Evangelist, all of which are regularly sent to me, contribute to generate and nourish this delusion, which the treacherous, furious, filthy and threatening Letters from the South on the same subject cannot sufficiently counteract— My duty to defend the free principles and Institutions is clear, but the measures by which they are to be defended are involved in thick darkness.— The path of right is narrow, and I have need of a perpetual controul over passion.
29. V. Monday

My cold is very troublesome, and much of this morning was consumed in assorting filing my Anti Slavery Petitions, of which I have now 120. on hand— Mr Ratcliff called and said he had now by the advice of his friends concluded to ask me to present the petition for the adoption of Legislative measures to promote the making the ship-canal across the Isthmus of Panama— He had proposed and I had urged him to get Edward Curtis to present it; but Mr Tallmadge had recommended that it should be presented by me and that its presentation to the Senate should be postponed for the present— H.R.U.S. It was petition day, and as the last Monday was passed over, I expected to have been delivered of my budget—but the Speaker took up the motion of reconsideration, of the commitment of the memorial of John Ross and the Cherokee Delegation, moved by Hopkins of Virginia— The commitment had been carried by a vote of 94 to 93— Everett expressed a wish to address the House; but the speaker said that the motion to lay on the table being not debateable a motion to reconsider a vote refusing to lay a subject on the
table must by necessary consequence be not debateable also. Everett took an appeal from this decision, but afterwards withdrew it requesting that the decision might be entered on the Journal— The Resolution to reconsider the commitment of the Cherokee Memorial was reconsidered by yeas and nays 122 to 80—and the memorial was laid on the table by 123 to 84— The Speaker then referred to certain Resolutions of the Legislature of Maine upon the North-eastern boundary, concerning which Evans had given notice of his intention to ask leave to bring in a Bill— But Evans moved to postpone the consideration of the subject till Thursday— There was a Message from the President with Documents relating to the Boundary question; which Evans moved should lay on the table and be printed to be taken up also on Thursday— By this time it was within a few minutes of one O’Clock. The Speaker called for Petitions from Maine—but without passing to the next State, announced the order of the day—the Mississippi election— Bronson finished his everlasting Speech— Jenifer of Maryland and Robertson of Virginia then made short Speeches in favour of the election of Prentiss and Word— Legare took the floor on the other side, but it was 4. O’Clock and the House adjourned in despite of the whigs who wanted to take the question this day— They delude themselves with the expectation that the House will reverse its former decision—and are fearful of losing stragglers by delay— I met behind the Bar Mr M’Keon, a member of the last Congress from New-York— The French Minister Pontois, with Saligny and the Vicomte de Montmaur— M’Keon told me that he was in favour of the Canadian Rebels— Evening sick and consumed time in assorting and minuting petitions— [symbols]
30 V. Tuesday.

My cold is distressing, disabling, and discouraging— It is now followed by sore throat most troublesome in the night and with impaired unfitting me for the labours of the day. By a new arrangement of the
mails that from the North comes in at Night instead of the morning, and last Night at ten O’Clock there came a budget of Newspapers and about twenty Anti-Slavery petitions in addition to the twenty that I had received in the morning— This morning Mr Michael Nourse came to make enquiries, as to the probability that Congress would grant lots of the public grounds in this City for the culture of silk and the worm— I gave him little encouragement, but said I would press the subject upon the consideration of the Committee of manufactures at their meeting next Thursday; and I advised him to consult the chairman of the Committee of Agriculture to which his subject has also been referred by the House.— Mr M’Caleb a young lawyer from New Orleans, came to enquire if there were any documents to which he could recur to shew upon what grounds this Government had maintained that West-Florida was included in the cession of Louisiana; and particularly whether it had been discussed at the negotiation of the Florida Treaty in 1819. I told him it had not— That the pretension had first been started by Mr Monroe and Mr Livingston, after the conclusion of their Florida & France Treaty but Spain had indignantly remonstrated against it— France had pronounced decidedly against it; and it had been given up by Mr Jefferson— Afterwards when Bonaparte conquered Spain there were commotions and insurrections in Florida; and political confusions till the negotiation of the Treaty by which both the Florida’s were ceded, and as that was to give us possession of the whole nothing was said between Mr Onis and me of preceding disputes about the parts— Mr M’Caleb said he wanted the information, for the management of some land-claims under grants from the Spanish Government, now pending before the Supreme Court of the United States— H.R.U.S— The Speaker consumed the whole morning hour within ten minutes in calling for reports from
Committees— M’Kay chairman of the military Committee reported a Bill to increase the army. The Speaker then announced my call on the President for the copy and translation of Gorostiza’s pamphlet, with the name of the foreign functionary, who communicated a copy of it to the Secretary of State— The pending question was upon Howard’s motion to strike out the call for the name— Howard said that when the subject was last before the house, Mr Cushing had the floor intending to address the House—he moved therefore that the subject should be postponed till to-morrow— To this I objected, and said I had understood Mr Cushing had no particular desire to say any thing further on this question and I was very anxious to have a decision of the House on the Call; it being necessary for the house to know what the pamphlet was before the could judge of the propriety of the heavy charges against it in the Report of the Secretary of State. I believed that the Secretary had totally misapprehended the character of Mr Gorostiza’s offence which at the worst appeared to be nothing more than an indiscretion— He had represented it as an unexampled outrage, and held it up as the preeminent provocation authorising the breaking up of all friendly negotiation with Mexico— That it was from being unexampled, I referred to the case of the French Revolutionary Minister Genet who appealed from the administration of President Washington to the People— Here the Speaker interrupted me, and announced the order of the day the Mississippi Election. Legare of South Carolina now made his justificatory Speech. He had flashed and foamed upon it at the special Session by an argument in gaudy colours, but totally destitute judgment— The case on Constitutional and legal grounds is clear as day— Legare darkens counsel with words— The whole of his Speech today was a labour uphill of an argument which was continually recoiling upon him— As soon as Legaré finished Cushman started up to move the previous question;
But Evans of Maine was also on the floor and the Speaker, who does not see Cushman as quickly as he did in the last Congress, gave the floor to Evans, who answered Foster, Bronson, Pennybacker and Legare— To answer one of them was to answer all— Evans’s talents, fine talents have gone into eclipse, with his character.— When he closed Cushman made his motion for the previous question— Prentiss however claimed his privilege of reply to the speeches made against his election and Cushman withdrew his motion— Mason of Virginia then asked to address the house, and announced that he had changed his opinion since the special Session— He then voted for the Resolution declaring Claiborne and Gholson elected for the 25th Congress— He now has State rights scruples of Conscience against nullifying a State Law by a Resolution of the House and therefore will vote for rescinding the Resolution in favour of Claiborne and Gholson, and then will vote that Prentiss and Word, are also not duly elected— Mason’s intellect has only half administered to his conscience— He votes to rescind his own former vote, because it clashed with the Law, of the State of Mississippi, and he now sets aside the same Law of the State of Mississippi, to deprive her two members of their seats, and the People of Mississippi of their representation on this floor for at least four months— Here was a new bone pick for deliberation, and M’Kay of North-Carolina, a perpetual halter between two opinions sustained Mason— The House adjourned shortly before 5. O’Clock— The children went to a children’s Ball at Mr Clagetts— Labouring with head ache, hoarseness and a sore throat, I retired early in the Evening to bed—

I had a very indifferent night, and am so hoarse, with a threatening sore throat that I hesitated at going out this morning, I could not prevail upon myself to keep house. Benjamin Tyler was here this morning, full of confidence and . . . glorification in his present situation and prospects—
He has discovered a varnish of marvelous perfection, and has full occupation and great success in using it— He was several months in a hospital in Philadelphia, but now lives in a good house at New-York; and is in want of nothing; his varnish providing for his subsistence and that of his wife— He is grateful for the aid received from me and Mr Butler the Attorney General, when he was in want at Philadelphia, and hopes to repay me soon. He invited me to go and see his varnished paintings at his lodgings but I have not time; so he sent me two signpost daubs which he calls Ferdinand and Isabella with his varnish upon them. H.R.U.S— When the Speaker called over the Committees for reports, Wise enquired of all the Committees on expenditures successively whether they were ready to report. Two thirds of them did not answer at all, and the rest of them had done nothing. W. Cost Johnson made a report from the select Committee on the question between the Serjeant at arms Dorsey and the Bank of the Metropolis—that the Committee had found 3816 dollars due from the Bank to Mr Dorsey, and that they had promptly paid the money— The Committee asked to be discharged from the further consideration of the subject, which was done, and their report was ordered to be printed— My call for Gorostiza’s pamphlet came up again— I referred to the cases of Yrujo both with Mr Pickering and Mr Madison in 1798 and 1806. to the case of Francis James Jackson with Robert Smith in 1809. and to the intercepted Letter from Luis de Onis to the Governor General of Caraccas confidentially communicated to Congress by President Madison in 1811— I read some of the Papers from a Volume of the National Intelligencer for 1806— Again arrested by the expiration of the hour and the Mississippi Election— Call of the House. Cushman moves the previous question and fails 107 to 111. question to rescind the Resolution of 3. October declaring Claiborne and Gholson elected members of the 25th. Congress carried 119 to 112. Haynes hops up from his place and makes a silly Speech.— Howard angles and tangles.— Wild and ludicrous commotion in the house— The house adjourned about 5. O’Clock, and I came home quite sick.
